Strain engineering of metal-based nanomaterials for energy electrocatalysis
Our research interests focus on advanced catalytic materials for fuel cells and hydrogen production. This work reviews recent advances on strain-engineered structures associated with lattice strain as well as microstrain from mechanistic and electrocatalytic perspectives.

Strain engineering of metal-based nanomaterials for energy electrocatalysis
Zhonghong Xiaa and Shaojun Guo *ab
The strain effect, along with the ligand effect and synergistic effect, contributes primarily to the
optimization of electrocatalytic activity and stability. The strain effect leads to a shift in the d-band
center and alters binding energies toward adsorbates. Under electrocatalytic circumstances, the strain
effect and ligand effect by and large function in combination; however, the decay and vanishing of the
ligand effect precede the strain effect as the thickness of the shell in the core/shell structure or metallic
overlayers on substrates increases. The strain effect on electrocatalytic activity can be well engineered
by tuning the thickness of shells or atomic composition. Microstrain, or localized lattice strain, is another
type of strain associated with structural defects such as grain boundaries and multi-twinning. In this
review, we discuss the origin of the strain effect and how it affects electrocatalytic activity based on the
d-band model. We present the structural characterization and quantitative determination of strain.
Metal-based nanocrystals are basically grouped into two types of structures to which the strain
engineering applies, i.e. lattice strain-associated structures (which include the general core/shell structure
and solid solution alloy) and multiple defects-induced structures. Then analysis is performed on the
correlation of strain and ligand effects and on the tuning strategies of the strain effect for electrocatalysis.
After that, we use representative examples to demonstrate how strain engineering assists in typical
electrocatalytic reactions on anodes and cathodes. Finally, we summarize and propose potential research
areas in terms of enhancing electrocatalytic activities by strain engineering in the future.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
In the past few decades, metal-based nanocatalysts have garnered increasing attention since they display superior electrocatalytic properties. The enhanced electrocatalytic activities are closely related to the ligand effect, strain effect as well as synergistic effect.1–5 a Department of Materials Science & Engineering, College of Engineering, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China. E-mail: guosj@pku.edu.cn b BIC-ESAT, College of Engineering, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China
Zhonghong Xia
Zhonghong Xia is currently a postdoctoral fellow under the supervision of Prof. Shaojun Guo at Peking University. He received his PhD degree in Engineering from College of Engineering, Peking University in 2018. His research interests include the design, synthesis and characterization of nanostructured materials applied in various electrocatalytic reactions.
Shaojun Guo
Shaojun Guo is a Professor of College of Engineering, Peking University and Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry. He received his BSc degree in chemistry from Jilin University (2005) and PhD degree in analytical chemistry from Chinese Academy of Sciences (2011). He joined Prof. Shouheng Sun’s group as a postdoctoral research associate at Brown University (2011–2013) and then worked as J. Robert Oppenheimer Distinguished Fellow at Los Alamos National Lab (2013–2015).
His research interests are in engineering nanocrystals and 2D materials for catalysis, renewable energy, optoelectronics and biosensors.

The ligand effect underscores the weakening/strengthening of binding of adsorbates induced by downshift/upshift of the d-band center (denoted as ed hereafter) which is essentially caused by the interaction between the d-bands of constituent metals in alloys.1 The strain effect, generated by lattice mismatch, alters adsorption energies by also the change in ed through the long-range effect (usually less than 6 monolayers away from the surface, longer than the ligand effect (1–2 monolayers)).2,4,5 The strain effect occurs in the core/shell structure wherein the core and shell possess different lattice parameters, and in the solid solution alloy wherein the atoms of a metal with different lattice parameters are incorporated into the lattice of another metal. Recently, microstrain, or localized lattice strain, closely associated with structural defectiveness such as grain boundary, has also been rationalized to enhance electrocatalytic activity and stability based on different mechanisms with the foregoing strain effect.6–8 As opposed to the discernible change in the peak position of X-ray diffraction spectra for the core/shell structure and solid solution alloy, microstrain corresponds to peak broadening without a shift of the peak position for multiple defects-induced structures.6–8 To distinguish them from each other, the strain effect will henceforth only denote the lattice mismatch-induced strain in this review. The synergistic effect arises as different steps in the whole mechanism are catalyzed by different reactive sites in the alloys.3 In the context of electrocatalysis, reactions usually involve the binding of chemisorbed species, and these effects function in combination to affect the binding strength of molecules.1,5 Here in this review, we direct our attention to the systematic contribution of strain engineering for electrocatalytic applications. The basics, characterization, structures, and electrocatalytic application of the strain effect will be discussed in detail as below.

sections.heading: 2 Basics of the strain effect
sections.text:
Before we get into the strain effect, it is necessary to have a brief understanding of the electronic band structure when adsorbate molecules are adsorbed onto the metals. Research conducted by Norskov and co-workers makes a critical contribution to the development of the d-band model.2,9,10 The valence state of the adsorbate undergoes coupling with metal s states and then turns to metal d states for coupling, and the interaction of the adsorbate with metal d states results in the separation of d states into bonding and anti-bonding states (Fig. 1).4,9,11 Bonding and anti-bonding d states of metals will be formed during the interaction with adsorbate molecules. Adsorbate binding will be strengthened with the filled bonding states and unfilled anti-bonding states, and the occupancy of anti-bonding states is only associated with their location with respect to the Fermi level.4,9
The change of the d-band structure in the tensile strain case is illustrated in Fig. 2a and b, where a metal atom with a smaller lattice parameter is inserted into the lattice, or is deposited as an overlayer onto the surface of a metal with a larger lattice parameter.10 The d-bandwidth decreases because the overlap
of d states between neighboring metal atoms narrows due to enlarged interatomic distances. For a transition metal with a more than half-filled d band (Ni in this case), its d-band center will undergo upshift relative to the Fermi level in order to maintain the fixed d occupancy. With the upshift of the d-band center, antibonding d states will move upward accompanied by decreased occupation, thereby leading to the strengthened adsorption interaction with reaction intermediates. Likewise, for Pt atoms deposited onto the Cu surface or inserted into the Cu lattice, the contracted Pt lattice gives rise to its increased d-bandwidth. The corresponding downshift in the d-band center weakens the adsorption strength toward reaction intermediates (Fig. 2c).
Consider oxygen reduction reaction (hereafter denoted as ORR) as an example. This cathodic reaction occurring in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) follows two pathways, i.e. dissociative mechanism and associative mechanism.12 The dissociative mechanism goes mainly in steps 1–3 (* refers to the surface site of the catalyst):
(1/2)O2 + * - O* (1)
O* + H+ + e - OH* (2)
OH* + H* + e - H2O + * (3)
The oxygen molecule is subject to adsorption, O–O bond cleavage and hydrogenation. The oxygenated species O* and OH* are ORR intermediates. As opposed to the dissociative mechanism, the associative mechanism does not involve O–O bond cleavage before hydrogenation; the oxygenated species, however, are formed during the associative process as well.12
It has been well accepted that oxygen (O*) adsorption energy, EO, serves as a descriptor for ORR rates (Fig. 2d and e).
13 Obviously the oxygen adsorption energy weakens (becomes more positive) as the d-band center moves away from the Fermi level. The correlation of activity with EO follows the volcano-like curve, wherein on the ascending side, the too strong adsorption strength of oxygen hampers desorption of oxygenated species, which block the catalytic surface, while too weak adsorption results in restricted oxygen molecule dissociation on the descending side.13

sections.heading: 3 Structural characterization and determination of strain
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) is a straightforward way for characterizing lattice strain. The incorporation of another metal with a dissimilar lattice constant results in the positive or negative shift of the peak position due to lattice contraction or expansion, respectively. Temmel et al. proposed the evaluation of out-of-plane tensile strain (ezz) on Pt films grown on the SrTiO3 substrate based on the shift in XRD peak positions of Pt films, and in-plane compressive strain (exx) can then be derived by taking the Poisson ratio into account (ezz = 2n/(1 n) exx).14 For a core/shell structure, lattice strain values are determined mostly by building structure models via density functional theory (DFT) calculations, or by postulating that the shell adopts the lattice parameter of the core due to epitaxial growth on the core before the shell is being relaxed.1,4,14–16 The latter links strain with the deviation of the lattice constant of the shell or film from its bulk or fully relaxed counterparts (strain = (astrained abulk)/abulk, astrained and abulk denote the lattice constants of the strained and bulk shell or film, respectively).4,14
Anomalous X-ray diffraction (AXRD) was also used to determine the surface structure as well as lattice strain.17 The AXRD profiles of the as-synthesized PtCu3 film and dealloyed Pt–Cu film can be fitted to one peak and two peaks (peaks 1 and 2), respectively. As the X-ray energy approached the Cu adsorption edge, the (111) integrated scattering intensity for both as-synthesized PtCu3 film
and peak 2 of the dealloyed Pt–Cu film weakened, which was in stark contrast with the almost unchanged integrated intensity for peak 1 of the dealloyed Pt–Cu film. Then peak 1 was ascribed to the Pt surface layer without Cu, and peak 2 was ascribed to the interior region with a certain content of Cu.17
Zhu et al. developed an approach to vividly characterize the relative values or trend of lattice strain via aberration-corrected high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) as well as image simulations (Fig. 3).15 By establishing the correlation of the triangle unit within the dashed rectangles with the lattice parameter and with strain (lattice contraction), they illustrated the two-dimensional lattice strain mapping with gradient variation from the surface to the core of nanoparticles. The percolated regions of lattice contraction are noticeable for the core of dealloyed PtFe nanoparticles with a Pt shell and a PtFe alloy core (Fig. 3a and b). In contrast, no continuous strain arises at the surface or the core of pure Pt nanoparticles, as seen from the randomly or sporadically distributed contraction or expansion within the particle (Fig. 3c and d).
Cui and coworkers reported a novel approach for strain engineering, wherein Pt nanoparticles deposited via atomic layer deposition (ALD) are tensilely or compressively strained when the LiCoO2 substrate undergoes the charging or discharging process, respectively.18 Li ions are extracted during the charging process, hence the structural change from LiCoO2 to Li0.5CoO2 and the concomitant expansion of interlayer spacing; Li ions intercalate back and interlayer spacing decreases back during

They provided explicit evidence of lattice compression/expansion by aligning compressed/expanded Pt(111) lattice fringes with pristine Pt to show the decreased/increased interlayer spacing of Pt (Fig. 4c and d).18 Meanwhile, integrated pixel intensities of Pt(111) facets were illustrated to give a clear image of the variation in average spacing during charging and discharging processes of the substrates (Fig. 4a and b). The Pt(111) spacing reduced from 2.29 Å in pristine L0.5CO–Pt to 2.18 Å in Li-intercalated L0.5CO–PtC, corresponding to the compressive
strain of ca. 5% in the discharging process. The larger lattice change of Pt (ca. 5%) relative to the LiCoO2 substrate (ca. 3%) arises due to the nonuniform variation of Li concentration on the surface and in the bulk of the oxide substrate. Similarly, Pt(111) spacing increased from 2.29 Å to 2.42 Å in delithiated LCO–PtT, indicative of ca. 5.7% tensile strain.
X-ray emission spectra (XES) as well as X-ray adsorption spectra (XAS) are used to illustrate the change in occupied and unoccupied states due to lattice strain, respectively.4,9 By examining the strain effect on dealloyed Pt–Cu with a Pt-rich surface, the Strasser group showed that as compressive strain on surface Pt layers increases, the antibonding resonance of XAS spectra becomes attenuated and finally vanishes at the maximal strain of 3.3%, meaning the antibonding states are filled corresponding to the lowermost d-band center for Pt (Fig. 5).4 For Au–Ni/Pt monolayer core/shell structures with AuNi alloy or AuNi core/shell nanocrystals as cores, the strain effect was illustrated by the Adzic group based on the change in the Au–Au bonding distance in the r space of Fourier-transform extended X-ray adsorption fine structure (FT-EXAFS) spectra.19 The Au lattice contraction for the AuNi alloy is more noticeable than is for the AuNi core/shell nanoparticle, as evidenced by the more significant decrease in the Au–Au bonding distance of the AuNi alloy as compared to Au foil. The higher degree of Au lattice contraction results in contraction of the as-deposited Pt monolayer; the d-band center of the Pt monolayer moves downward accordingly.

sections.heading: 4.1 Lattice strain-associated structure
sections.text:
Lattice strain engineering mostly manifests itself in two types of structures, general core/shell structure and solid solution alloy. The two structures are lumped together as a group since strain resulting from differing lattice constants rather than structural

defects is at play. By ‘‘general core/shell structure’’, we herein refer to all structures analogous to the core/shell structure such as pseudomorphic overlayers on substrates. For the solid solution alloy, the strain effect is induced by the incorporation of solute atoms with different lattice constants into the solvent metal lattice.
4.1.1 General core/shell structure. Core/shell structures were usually synthesized via seed-mediated growth, galvanic replacement reaction, electrochemical dealloying and thermal annealing-induced Pt segregation.4,20,21 The strain effect on Pt-based ORR electrocatalysts was demonstrated via electrochemical dealloying of Pt–Cu and PtxNi1 x alloys (PtNi, PtNi3, etc.) for oxygen reduction catalysis by modulating the compositional distribution.17,22,23 Dealloyed PtNi3 and PtNi5 formed a sandwichlike structure that consisted of a Pt outer shell at the surface, a Ni-enriched inner shell at the near-surface region, and a Ni-depleted core.23 The possible mechanism of Ni-enriched inner shell formation is that the oxygen adsorption-induced outward diffusion of Ni atoms was impeded by the Pt outer shell that serves as a barrier, which results in Ni enrichment underneath the Pt outer shell. The higher degree of compressive strain on the Pt surface due to higher Ni content in the Ni-enriched inner shell made the dealloyed PtNi3 alloy stand out among the three alloys in terms of ORR catalytic activity. The strain engineering was also demonstrated through the growth of the Pt monolayer shell on the metallic core.19,24,25 The Pt monolayer was mainly synthesized by galvanic replacement reaction of the Pt precursor with the Cu monolayer that is formed by underpotential deposition (upd). The AuNi alloy and Au–Ni core/shell nanoparticle were used as cores to elucidate the dependence of the strain effect and catalytic activity on core materials.19 As discussed in Section 3, the AuNialloy core/Pt
monolayer shell nanoparticles possessed weakened affinity towards oxygenated species and the highest ORR activity, with mass activity and specific activity exhibiting 7-fold and 5-fold improvement relative to Pt/C, respectively.
A pseudomorphic overlayer (Pt, Pd, etc.) is also a type of core/ shell-like structure to which the lattice strain effect applies due to the difference in the lattice constants of the overlayer and the substrate. The overlayers, prepared by electrodeposition or electron beam deposition and grown epitaxially on substrates, enable uniform distribution of the strain and serve as good cases for the analysis of the strain effect.5,26,27 Sibert et al. discovered the potentialinduced strain variation that occurred in Au bilayer/monolayer films on Pt(111).27 For the Au bilayer film, the potential-induced structural evolution involves first a dislocation-free (1 1) phase, then a striped phase and finally a hex phase (with a hexagonal pattern), while for the Au monolayer film, the phase transition is similar to the bilayer film except that the hex phase is missing. The striped phase is characterized by dislocation lines whose density is dependent upon the potential. The dislocation lines are associated with the relaxation, or expansion, of surface layer spacings of the close-packed structure via the adsorption of anions, as the potential becomes more positive. As such, the Au surface layer subject to compressive strain at lower potential is relaxed to form a bulk-like structure at higher potential.
4.1.2 Solid solution alloy. The solid solution alloy is another archetypal lattice strain-engineered structure. The solute metal atoms incorporated into the lattice of the solvent metal may give rise to lattice strain without changing the crystal lattice of the solvent metal. This is quite common for Pt-based and Pd-based alloys wherein the inclusion of a second metal with a smaller lattice parameter results in a shift of the XRD peak position toward higher angles due to compressive strain.22,24,25 The XRD spectra correspond to the Pt and Pd face-centered cubic (fcc) structure without the formation of impurity phases.
As a matter of fact, solid solution alloys and core/shell structures are usually combined to achieve the fine tailoring of the lattice strain effect.19,22,23 The electrochemically dealloyed Pt-based nanocrystals mostly consist of a Pt-based solid solution alloy as a core and Pt as a shell.17,22,23 The PtxNi1 x (Pt1.5Ni, PtNi, PtNi1.5) nanocrystals turned from octahedra to concave octahedra with a Pt-enriched frame along corners and edges after preferential leaching from the Ni-rich {111} facet during electrochemical dealloying.22 The dealloyed PtNi alloy possessed a Pt shell of 1–4 atomic layers and stabilized Pt{111} facets at the bottom of the concave pit; as such, the strain effect together with the ligand effect at the near-surface region contributes to the enhancement of ORR activity of dealloyed PtNi nanocrystals. In contrast, the strain effect and ligand effect are weakened for dealloyed Pt1.5Ni nanocrystals with a relatively thick Pt shell of 5–12 atomic layers; as regards dealloyed PtNi1.5 nanocrystals, the disappearance of active {111} facets during dealloying also deteriorates their ORR activity.

The term ‘‘microstrain’’ was usually used to describe strain particularly associated with multiple structural defects characteristic of grain boundaries formed on a hollow, sea sponge or aggregated structure.6–8 Microstrain, or local lattice strain, is generated from structural defects such as dislocation, grain boundaries, and twinned boundaries, the likes of which alter the surface electronic structure and/or atomic arrangements.6–8 Different from lattice strain characterized by the change in interatomic spacings, microstrain indicates the atoms’ deviation from the ideal sites.6,8 Furthermore, lattice strain due to alloying results in the shift of the XRD peak positions, while microstrain causes peak broadening rather than position change. Microstrain can be determined via Rietveld refinement of the X-ray diffraction or scattering patterns.6,8 It should be noted that microstrain also exists in the core/shell structure. For instance, a core/shell structure featured by atomic vacancies or cavities can be created via dealloying, i.e. selective dissolution of non-noble metals from the alloys.7,8
On comparing a series of PtNi alloy nanocrystals (solid, aggregated, core/shell, hollow and sea sponge structures), the results showed that sea sponge PtNi and hollow PtNi nanocrystals with abundant grain boundaries had the lowest COads oxidation potential and the highest ORR activity relative to reference Pt, with sea sponge PtNi exhibiting 5.8-fold enhancement in mass activity relative to reference Pt.6 They also demonstrated that the N2-treated hollow PtNi retained its defect-rich structure and its superiority to H2-/air-treated solid PtNi as well as reference Pt in terms of ORR activity after the accelerated stress test (AST), even though N2-treated hollow PtNi underwent activity degradation due to Ni dissolution in an acidic electrolyte and the loss in specific surface areas due to the structural collapse of a portion during AST.8 The result is consistent with the fact that the hollow structure remained after the thermal annealing of as-synthesized hollow PtNi in N2, while thermal annealing in H2 or air disrupted the hollow structure and contributed to the formation of solid compact nanocrystals with noticeably lower density of structural defects and microstrain value.
Multiple structural defects can also emerge and expand with an external influence such as ion irradiation apart from in situ growth during the synthesis.28 Our group synthesized PtPb nanoplates with a surface enriched in defects and phase boundaries via the C+ ion irradiation approach.28 PtPb nanoplates with optimized defects/interfaces displayed mass activity/specific activity with 25.8-/25.9-fold improvement toward MOR catalysis and with 23.3-/21.5-fold improvement toward ORR catalysis relative to commercial Pt/C. The remarkable catalytic activity was attributed to multiple structural defects composed of dislocation, subgrain boundaries and crystal–amorphous phase boundaries. Point defects were formed upon collision of ion irradiation on single-crystalline PtPb nanoplates and the structure turned to be polycrystalline. Phase boundaries were gradually generated as a result of the spreading amorphous zone which arose from dislocation and subgrain boundaries.
The hybrid metallic nanostructures with unusual crystal phases that are rich in stacking faults were also shown to have superior electrocatalytic activity.29,30 The Zhang group reported
Ru nanorods hetero-epitaxially grown on the 4H phase and fcc twin boundary of Au nanowires.29 The 4H phase of Au nanowires affords chief nucleation sites (83.3%) for Ru nanorods as compared to the fcc twin boundary (16.7%). The stacking sequence of the 4H phase allowed for the formation of rough surfaces and controllable Ru nanorods. In terms of HER catalytic activity, the resultant Au–Ru hybrid nanowires had significantly lower overpotential (50 mV) to reach 10 mA cm 2 relative to Ru/C (116 mV) and Pt/C (94 mV). The Tafel slope of the hybrid Au–Ru nanowires is comparable to that of Pt/C (30.8 mV dec 1 vs. 30.6 mV dec 1) and greatly lower than that of Ru/C (30.8 mV dec 1 vs. 47.8 mV dec 1). They also synthesized lotus-thalamus-shaped Pt–Ni anisotropic superstructures (ASs) composed of a Ni-rich ‘‘core’’ with a face-centred cubic (fcc) phase, Ni-rich ‘‘arms’’ with a hexagonal close-packed (hcp) phase, and Pt-rich ‘‘lotus seeds’’ with a fcc phase.30 The distinct atomic arrangement of the hcp phase, coupled with lowcoordinated step atoms at the side surfaces of the ‘‘arm’’, could enhance HER catalytic activity.
Multi-twinned morphology, an archetypal kind of structural defect, has been proved to promote electrocatalytic activity.31–34 For Pt-based icosahedral and octahedral nanocrystals with similar average sizes, it was found that they differ from spherical nanocrystals due to their predominant {111} facets, while they distinguish themselves from one another due to dissimilar surface strains and adsorption strength, leading to different ORR catalysis.33,34 Moreover, multi-twinned defects serve as catalytic active sites by facilitating adsorption and activation of reaction molecules.32
Recently, surface distortion (SD) was proposed as a measure of ORR activity and long-term stability and correlated with microstrain values.7 For structurally ordered catalysts free of defects, microstrain resulted from chemical disorder that was caused by inhomogeneous alloying of metal atoms (case (iii) in Fig. 6b), while for structurally disordered catalysts, grain boundaries interconnecting individual crystallites (case (ii) in Fig. 6b), and atomic vacancies generated by dealloying-induced surface buckling (case (iv) in Fig. 6b), led to a high microstrain value related to peak broadening instead of peak position shift of wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) spectra (Fig. 6a). Strategies of tuning activities for two classes of electrocatalysts differ, wherein the aim is to search for active sites with optimal oxygen adsorption strength for structurally ordered electrocatalysts with low or no SD, i.e. monocrystalline electrocatalysts under homogeneous strain, while the active sites are those with oxygen adsorption strength closest to the optimal values for structurally disordered electrocatalysts (SD 4 0) with a wide variety of catalytic sites (Fig. 6c and d). The correlation was established between surface defect- or surface distortion-controlled microstrain and catalytic activities.
The variation in the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates has recently been correlated with the microstrain-tuned structure via the introduction of the generalized coordination
number CN denoted as the second-nearest neighbor or the coordination number of the first-nearest neighbor for a specific site.35,36 It was shown that concave sites with CN approaching the optimum of 8.3 promoted ORR catalytic activity, while convex

sections.heading: 5 Correlation of the strain effect with the ligand effect
sections.text:
In many cases the strain effect and the ligand effect function in synergy and they show additivity in terms of changing free energy of adsorption.1,37,38 Some reports also showed the opposing effects of strain and ligand as the content of transition metal or surface alloying increases, wherein the strain effect tends to increase catalytic activity while the ligand effect decreases activity.39 For Pt film deposited on Ru(0001), the electronic effect prevailed as the thickness of Pt films ranged from 1 ML (monolayer) to 3 ML, thereby contributing to a further decrease in CO adsorption energies compared with purely strained Pt films.5 The electronic effect vanished and the strain effect played a significant role for n Z 4 Pt layers; strain was partially released owing to the formation of large-scale dislocation networks only for n Z 5 Pt layers.5 The strain and ligand effects on hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysis by Pd overlayers on M (Rh, Ir, Pt and Au) were examined.1 The difference of H adsorption energy between purely strained Pd(111) and Pd overlayers strongly indicates the existence of the ligand effect which depends on the Pd–M d-band interaction or hybridization. The ligand effect always drives ed to shift negatively and weakens H adsorption. The strain effect is associated with the lattice mismatch between Pd and M. For Pd/Pt with similar lattice parameters, the ligand effect prevails
while tensile strain is trivial relative to Pd/Au wherein the strain effect dominates. The ligand effect and the strain effect act in combination for the cases of Pd/Rh and Pd/Ir. The dependence of the strain effect on specific adsorbates in terms of CO2 electroreduction was examined,37 in which the ligand effect was at play for strain-insensitive adsorbates *CO and *COH, while the strain effect was actively involved for strain-sensitive adsorbates *COOH and *CHO. An intensive investigation on the strain effect and ligand effect for Pt monolayers on metallic substrates was further carried out.40,41 Among n monolayers of Pt deposited on the Pt25Ni75(111) single crystal (n ML-Pt/ Pt25Ni75, n = 2–4), the 2 ML-Pt/Pt25Ni75 possessed the highest ORR activity with an enhancement factor of 25 relative to Pt(111).40 This was in stark contrast with the volcano-like theoretical correlation of ORR activity with surface strain, wherein the 2.6% compressively strained Pt surface, corresponding to 2 ML-Pt/Pt25Ni75, attained an activity enhancement factor of only 5. The disparity was ascribed to the role of the ligand effect. The Pt 4f7/2 binding energies became lowered as the Pt shell thickness increased from 2 to 4 monolayers, signifying that the ligand effect between the topmost Pt shell and the Ni atoms in the substrate lessened. The strong ligand effect on 2 ML-Pt/Pt25Ni75 gave rise to its superb ORR activity. Also, the ORR activity of n monolayers of Pt deposited on the Ir(111) substrate at a substrate temperature of 673 K followed the order 673 K-Pt1mL/ Ir(111) o 673 K-Pt4mL/Ir(111) o 673 K-Pt3mL/Ir(111) o 673 KPt2mL/Ir(111).
41 The 673 K-Pt1mL/Ir(111) deviated from the trend wherein the activity increased as the Pt monolayer thickness decreased. This was explained by inhomogeneous surface composition due to the inter-diffusion (ligand effect) between substrate Ir and surface Pt, and by the exposure of inactive Ir atoms to the electrolyte due to the incomplete coverage of Ir substrate domains by the Pt monolayer.
Fig. 6 (a) WAXS patterns for structurally disordered and structurally ordered catalysts. sections.heading: 6 Tuning strategies for strain-driven electrocatalysis
sections.text:
The scope of the lattice strain effect can reasonably be engineered according to the thickness of shells or overlayers; as such, the optimal interaction with adsorbates or reaction intermediates can be achieved.4,5,14 The study on CO2 electroreduction by Pt-supported Cu overlayers with various thicknesses (monolayer, 5 nm and 15 nm) demonstrated that the formation and selectivity of hydrocarbons (methane and ethylene) increased as the overlayer thickness became larger.42 The results could be explained by the fact that with thicker Cu overlayers deposited on Pt, the exposure of Pt atoms, which are actually HER active sites, was effectively suppressed, even though Pt exhibited affinity toward CO, an intermediate species during CO2 electroreduction. 43 Epitaxial Pt films on the SrTiO3 substrate underwent several typical scenarios during their growth: pure substrate (0 min), separated islands (6 nm thickness), percolated network (12 nm thickness, ‘‘strained’’ film) and finally homogeneous Pt films (24 nm thickness, ‘‘relaxed’’ film) (Fig. 7a–d).14 In terms of specific charges (Qspec) derived from the Hupd deposition region, relaxed Pt film (4160) is noticeably higher than strained Pt film (o160), since steps and edges with (100) facets have affinity for hydrogen adsorption, while hydrogen adsorption is impeded for strained Pt film (Fig. 7e). CO oxidation voltammograms show that oxidation peak potential follows the order of Pt(111) single crystal (0.777 V) o relaxed Pt film (0.781 V) o strained Pt film (0.798 V), suggestive of the weakened OH adsorption affinity on strained Pt film (Fig. 7f). Moreover, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) specific activities showed an 8-fold increase from relaxed to strained Pt films (Fig. 7g).
Recent reports also underscored the importance of immediate atomic composition to strain tuning.22,23,44 The Mukerjee group demonstrated that the linear correlation of ORR activity and
in situ Co/Pt atomic composition could be bridged by the strain descriptor, i.e. bulk average Pt–Pt bonding distance, RPt–Pt.
44 The in situ rather than initial Co/Pt atomic composition was considered to be a significant factor because as initial Co concentration increased, Co atoms were more severely leached during acid pretreatment. The residual Co content after acid dissolution for various PtxCo alloys was actually very similar. The phenomenon was in good agreement with the result that the bulk composition of Pt3Ni was obtained after electrochemical dealloying activation of three PtxNi1 x alloys, namely, Pt1.5Ni, PtNi, and PtNi1.5. 22

sections.heading: 7.1 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)
sections.text:
Oxygen reduction is an ideal reaction to examine the strain effect on the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates and/or improvement of mass/specific activities.45–49 Regarding ORR catalysis, the strain effect can also be visualized by suppressed H adsorption via downshift in adsorption potential or reduced specific charge in the underpotential deposition hydrogen (Hupd) zone, and by weakened OH adsorption via upshift in OH adsorption or oxidation potential.14,41
Our group carried out continuous research regarding synthesis and ORR catalysis of core/shell and ultrathin nanowires by capitalizing on the strain effect and/or high-index facets.20,45–48 A new class of hierarchical Pt-based bimetallic nanowires with zigzag or screw-like morphology were prepared.45,47 Driven by the interdiffusion of Pt and Co atoms, Pt3Co hierarchical nanowires grew from ultrathin nanowires to zigzag-like nanowires with uneven surfaces characteristic of noticeable humps (Fig. 8a).45 The [310] high-index facets endowed Pt3Co hierarchical nanowires with exceptionally high ORR mass activity, specific activity,

Recently, we synthesized Pt-skin zigzag Pt3Fe nanowires (Pt-skin Pt3Fe z-NWs) by subjecting as-prepared zigzag Pt3Fe nanowires (Pt3Fe z-NWs) to thermal annealing under N2.
47 The Pt-skin with a thickness of two atomic layers was formed due to Pt segregation and high-index facets were well retained during thermal annealing (Fig. 8g–k). The Pt-skin Pt3Fe z-NWs, combined with a high-index faceted 1D nanowire morphology and protective Pt shell, showed extraordinary mass and specific ORR activities, which are 1.9/2.1 and 13.2/16.7 times higher compared to that of Pt3Fe z-NWs and commercial Pt/C respectively. Likewise, the ORR long-term stability of Pt-skin Pt3Fe z-NWs surpasses that of Pt3Fe z-NWs and commercial Pt/C considerably. The superior electrocatalytic activities of these zigzag-like nanowires can also reasonably be linked with the adsorption energy–surface coordination relation proposed by Calle-Vallejo et al. wherein cavities serve to improve ORR activity with nearly optimal CN.35,36 Ultrathin PtNiCo nanowires with a diameter of 0.8 nm exhibited remarkable ORR mass activity compared to ultrathin Pt nanowires and commercial Pt/C with improvement factors of 4.0 and 32.3, respectively.46 The strain effect together with the ligand effect upon the addition of Ni not only contributes to the relief of overbinding toward oxygen for pure Pt, but also enables more active adsorption sites such as the bridge site on the {100} facet and on the intersection of {111} facets, thereby leading to optimal oxygen adsorption.
The fcc-Fe51Pt49 (fcc: face centered cubic) bimetallic alloy was synthesized and subjected to heat treatment at 650 1C,
which gave rise to the fct-Fe51Pt49 (fct: face centered tetragonal) phase.49 Electrochemical dealloying gave rise to core/shell structured fct-Fe51Pt49/Pt and fcc-Fe51Pt49/Pt with a Pt shell thickness of 0.6 nm. ORR tests showed that the half-wave potential (E1/2) of fct-Fe51Pt49/Pt is 29 mV higher than that of fcc-Fe51Pt49/Pt, and the specific activity of the former is appreciably higher than that of the latter (2.1 vs. 0.89 mA cm 2). The difference in activity arises due to strain-induced variation of DEO. Conversion from fcc-FePt/Pt to fct-FePt/Pt caused reduction of compressive strain along [100] and [010] directions, which means compressive strain on the Pt shell was released, resulting in the strengthened oxygen adsorption. The DEO of fcc-FePt/Pt and fct-FePt/Pt are 0.26 eV and 0.23 eV, respectively, the latter of which is comparable to the optimal value of 0.20 eV attained by ideal Pt.
So far, there has been no unambiguous answer as to whether or not compressive strain enhances electrocatalytic activity, although numerous reports4,17 have shown that in terms of ORR catalysis, compressive strain boosts catalytic activity via downshift of the d-band center and the resultant decreased binding strength of reaction intermediates. This is consistent with the fact that oxygen adsorption on the flat Pt(111) surface is 0.2 eV stronger than the peak in the ‘‘volcano’’ plot, i.e. the ORR activity–oxygen adsorption energy plot.13
However, compressive strain does not universally enhance catalytic activities. Setting ORR catalysis as an example, it is understandable that too weak oxygen binding due to overcompression limits the rate of O2 dissociation and proton/ electron transfer.4 A typical example of tensile strain-induced

The mass activity and specific activity of the PtPb/Pt nanoplate reach 9.8-fold and 33.9-fold improvement as compared to the Department of Energy (U.S.) target and commercial Pt/C, respectively. Moreover, there is only 7.7% degradation in the mass activity of the PtPb/Pt nanoplate as opposed to 66.7% loss for commercial Pt/C after 50 000 sweeping cycles (Fig. 9e and f). The remarkable catalytic activity can be attributed to the hollow sites and bridge sites subject to tensile strains at edge-Pt and/or top-Pt surfaces (Fig. 9g–j). The tensile strain is beneficial in activating surface low-coordinated atoms, which enables optimal oxygen binding energies and facilitates ORR catalytic performances. The Wang group used PVP-capped Pd nanocubes as the precursor to synthesize Pd hydride nanocubes (PdH0.43) and finally Pd hydride nanocubes were encapsulated in Ni–B amorphous nanosheets (PdH0.706@Ni–B composites) by adding Ni and B sources.51 The lattice parameter kept increasing as H atoms were incorporated into the Pd lattice from the Pd nanocube to PdH0.43 and PdH0.706@Ni–B. The tensile lattice strain promoted the desorption of PVP from the surface when preparing PdH0.43 with the Pd nanocube. On the other hand, tensile strain weakened the adsorption strength towards oxygenated species for PdH0.706@Ni–B relative to PdH0.43. The PdH0.706@Ni–B showed ORR mass activity five times higher than that of Pt/C and almost no degradation after 10 000 potential cycles in an acid electrolyte.

Guo et al. manipulated a tensile strain of 3.5–0% on the MoS2 shell in Co9S8/nL MoS2 where n (the number of shell layers) ranged from 1 to 5 (Fig. 10a–e).16 Co9S8/1L MoS2 exhibited the highest HER catalytic activity among its counterparts with an overpotential of 95 mV vs. RHE and a Tafel slope of 71 mV dec 1 (Fig. 10f–i). The spectacular activity was associated with the optimal hydrogen adsorption energy (DEH) as well as the energy barrier of 2H*, a transition state from H to H2 (DE2H*). For Co9S8/ 1L MoS2, the DEH and DE2H* reached 1.03 eV and 0.29 eV, respectively, both of which were the lowest compared with those of the other four core/shell nanocrystals. The lowest hydrogen binding strength and energy barrier were attained due to the optimal band position relative to the Fermi level and charge density at Co–S–Mo interfaces. Voiry and coworkers fabricated WS2 nanosheets via lithium intercalation followed by chemical exfoliation.52 The as-exfoliated WS2 was characterized by a highly strained 1T structure, wherein large local strain arose due to the high density of kinks within the zigzag superlattice structure. Annealing of as-exfoliated 1T WS2 gave rise to 2H WS2 without structural distortion. 1T WS2 exhibited better HER activity with lower overpotentials and Tafel slopes. Theoretical evidence proved that tensile strain served to improve HER activity for as-exfoliated 1T WS2 rather than 2H WS2 since at a critical value of tensile strain, hydrogen adsorption free energy reached zero for 1T WS2. Yan et al. demonstrated an approach for in situ analysis of electrochemical response of metallic films supported on polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) substrates under externally applied elastic strains, wherein metallic film–PMMA composite electrodes were placed in the universal mechanical testing device during electrochemical experiments and the films could inherit the compressive or tensile loading applied to the substrates.53 As such, the separation of strain effects from ligand effects can be achieved via the application of mechanically induced strain to enable epitaxial growth of pseudomorphic overlayers. For PMMA-supported metal films, HER free energy diagrams indicate that for Pt and Ni, H* adsorption and H2 evolution are downhill and uphill, respectively, whereas for Cu the free energy change is the other way around. Then the rate-limiting steps for Pt/Ni and Cu are H2 evolution and H* adsorption, respectively. Improvement in HER activity can be achieved by weakening the H adsorption (in favor of H2 evolution) for Pt/Ni via compressive strain and strengthening the H adsorption for Cu via tensile strain. This also provides an answer with regard to whether compressive strain always promotes electrocatalytic activity.

Competitive hydrogen evolution reaction needs to be suppressed to improve product selectivity.38,43,54 Cu is by far the only metal to produce large amounts of hydrocarbons, although with a high overpotential.38,43,54 Considerable effort has been devoted to modifying the structure of Cu via the strain effect or electronic effect.37,38,43,54 Clark et al. systematically investigated the pivotal role of the strain effect of CuAg bimetallic alloys in determining the distribution of products.54 On CuAg bimetallic electrodes, HER catalytic activity was noticeably suppressed, while current density associated with CO-derived products was not negatively affected. The hypothesis that CO spillover occurred from Ag to Cu was demonstrated to be inconsistent with experimental results since the current density of CO generation was not inhibited. The strain effect was then introduced to elucidate the suppression of HER activity as well as the improvement of distribution of CO-derived products with the generation of carbonyl-containing products being boosted and that of hydrocarbons (typically ethene) being checked. Compressive strain, induced by the addition of Ag to the Cu surface, results in weakening of hydrogen adsorption due to the lower stability of hydrogen relative to CO under strain. Meanwhile, since the oxophilicity of Cu under compressive strain is reduced, the binding energy of acetaldehyde will become lower, enabling its desorption from the Cu surface and production of ethanol and acetate. Huang et al. synthesized octahedral and icosahedral Pd nanoparticles with almost the same average size and {111} facets by which both Pd nanocrystals were bounded (Fig. 11).31 Pd icosahedra surpassed Pd octahedra in terms of CO2 electroreduction activity (faradaic efficiencies of CO formation as well as CO partial current densities). The Pd icosahedron and octahedron atomic models exhibit a surface strain of +1.8% and 0.5%, respectively (Fig. 11e), which is consistent with the higher interlayer spacing of the Pd icosahedron (2.32 Å) relative to single-crystalline bulk Pd (2.25 Å) (Fig. 11d). Theoretical calculations also showed that tensile strain in Pd icosahedra gives rise to upshift of the d-band center (ed = 1.40 eV) and the stronger binding strength of adsorbates relative to Pd octahedra (ed = 1.48 eV) subject to compressive strain (Fig. 11f). This is also corroborated by lower formation energy of COOH* on Pd icosahedra (0.15 eV) than on Pd octahedra (0.19 eV).

sections.heading: 7.4 Alcohol/formic acid oxidation reaction (AOR/FAOR)
sections.text:
Oxidation of small molecules like methanol and formic acid involves direct and indirect mechanisms. The direct mechanism means conversion to CO2 without generation of poisonous intermediates, while CO is formed in the indirect mechanism; as such, weak adsorption of the CO intermediate is needed to facilitate small molecule oxidation.55,56 Celorrio et al. prepared Au/Pd core/shell nanoparticles with different Pd shell thickness (CS1: 1.3 nm, CS10: 9.9 nm).55 It turned out that the difference in the catalytic activity of HCOOH oxidation is dependent upon the strain-affected oxidation of HCOOads intermediates. As tensile strain increased from CS10 (1.0%) to CS1 (3.5%), the d-band center (ed) underwent upshift from 2.0066 eV to 1.7922 eV; the electronic effect is not accountable for the significant change in ed even if it is included. The adsorption of HCOOads intermediates is strengthened for CS1, which can be confirmed by the observable peak of HCOOads that arises with increasing potential (Fig. 12). The relatively short lifetime of HCOOads in the case of CS10 indicates that HCOOH oxidation might proceed by a different pathway, wherein HCOOads intermediates are rapidly oxidized in the presence of OHads due to the diminished binding strength of HCOOads. This, as well, demonstrates how shell or overlayer thickness influences electrocatalytic activity via the strain effect. Kuo et al. made comparisons of FAOR catalytic activities of Pd octahedra, Pd icosahedra, and Au/Pd core/shell octahedra.56 Pd icosahedra and Au/Pd core/shell octahedra have similar oxidation current densities and oxidation potentials, which are superior to

With less than 6 Pd atomic monolayers on the Au core, the lattice strain effect is pronounced for Au/Pd core/shell octahedra. Pt-Based bimetallic zigzag-like nanowires with high-index facets, tailored composition and Pt shell also exhibited extraordinary methanol oxidation or ethanol oxidation catalytic activity and durability, representing the rational design of promising 1D electrocatalysts by utilizing the strain effect and/or ligand effect.45,47 Huang et al. synthesized a series of trimetallic PtNiPd nanowires with a PtNi-rich shell and a Pd core.48 The morphological growth involves the formation of ultrathin PtNi nanowires as seeds, followed by the deposition of Pd and then the reduction of Pt and Ni; the outward diffusion of Pt and Ni gives rise to the PtNi shell. As far as the catalysis of ethylene glycol oxidation reaction (EGOR) and glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR) is concerned, PtNi0.56Pd1.42 nanowires exhibited the highest activity and stability, with EGOR specific activity and mass activity being 0.97 mA cm 2 and 0.54 A mgPt
1 respectively, and with GOR specific activity and mass activity being 0.44 mA cm 2 and 0.24 A mgPt
1. As mentioned above, electrocatalytic activity can also be boosted by tuning tensile lattice strain. The Xie group synthesized palladium hydride PdHx under solvothermal reaction of commercial Pd black and n-butylamine.57 The incorporation of H generated lattice expansion. Meanwhile, the interaction of Pd with H contributed to lower the d-band center, and the CO binding strength of PdHx diminished as the H content increased, which gave rise to the decrease of the onset potential of CO oxidation and the increase of FAOR catalytic activity.

sections.heading: 8 Summary and outlook
sections.text:
Constructing core/shell structures and solid solution alloys is still an efficient way to enhance electrocatalytic activity as the strain effect induced by the core or second metal can be maximized to tune the surface adsorption strength. Besides one-dimensional high-index faceted nanowires, strain engineering also applies to two-dimensional ultrathin nanosheets or nanoplates with highly exposed facets, distinct atomic arrangements and
enhanced specific surface areas. It is important to reveal the relation of electrocatalytic activity with strain across a certain range in order for activity to be more precisely tuned. The combination of X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy could better characterize lattice strain and reveal the effect of strain engineering on electrocatalytic activity. Meanwhile, it is possible that rational control of strain, from the perspective of particular facets such as (111), (100) and (110), can be achieved. As the thickness of the shell or overlayer increases, the ligand effect gradually decreases and vanishes while the strain effect is still at play. The continued increase of thickness also weakens the strain effect as a consequence of dislocation to release the accumulated strain. A growing number of reports have been focused on microstrainassociated structural defects such as atomic vacancies, grain boundaries, multi-twinning and stacking faults. Electrocatalysts with a high density of structural defects will also be highly desirable with their remarkable activity and durability. In addition, electrocatalytic activity can probably be improved by the formation of structural defects through external influences. Lastly, the rational design of electrocatalysts may require that the strain effect alongside the electronic effect and ensemble effect serve in combination to enhance electrocatalytic activities, in light of the fact that essentially those effects are all ascribed to the tuning of the d-band center, and that it is not always easy to distinguish those effects.
